explanation: WebSocket establishes a persistent bidirectional connection between client and server, allowing real-time updates with lower overhead compared to HTTP polling.

title: They increase architectural complexity
content: Explain the concept of micro-frontends and their trade-offs.
explanation: Micro-frontends split the UI into smaller, independently deployable apps. They improve scalability but increase complexity.

options.text: Micro-frontends allow independent teams to build and deploy parts of the UI
Micro-frontends always simplify performance optimization

title: This is incorrect. Please refer to system design best practices.
content: Discuss strategies like browser cache, CDN cache, service workers, and caching APIs.
explanation: Caching reduces redundant network requests and speeds up page loads. Browser caching handles static assets, CDN caching distributes content closer to users, and service workers enable offline support.

title: Lazy loading only applies to JavaScript modules, not images.
content: Explain lazy loading for images, components, and modules in a web app.
explanation: Lazy loading is especially useful for images, videos, and code-splitting in large applications.

options.text: Lazy loading defers the loading of non-critical resources until they are needed.
options.explanation: Helps reduce initial load time and improves perceived performance.

options.text: Lazy loading means loading all resources as early as possible.
Lazy loading only applies to JavaScript modules, not images.

title: Both approaches are identical
content: Describe the difference between optimistic and pessimistic updates in state management.
explanation: Optimistic updates update UI immediately before server confirmation. Pessimistic updates wait for server response.

options.text: Optimistic update: update UI before server confirms
Pessimistic update: update UI after server confirms
Both approaches are identical

title: Optimizes images automatically
content: Explain how tree-shaking helps in reducing bundle size and when it is most effective.
explanation: Tree-shaking removes unused code from bundles. It works best with ES6 module imports.

options.text: Removes unused CSS from the DOM
Removes unused JavaScript exports from bundles
Shakes DOM nodes to re-render faster
Optimizes images automatically

title: This is incorrect. Please refer to system design best practices.
content: Explain idempotency in APIs and its impact on frontend state consistency.
explanation: Idempotent APIs produce the same result no matter how many times they are called. They prevent duplicate state changes if frontend retries requests due to network issues.

options.text: Idempotent APIs produce the same result no matter how many times they are called. They prevent duplicate state changes if frontend retries requests due to network issues.

title: SSG cannot be cached on CDN.
content: Compare CSR, SSR, and SSG in terms of performance, SEO, and user experience.
explanation: CSR is good for highly interactive apps, SSR helps SEO-driven apps like e-commerce, and SSG is ideal for blogs, docs, and marketing sites.

options.text: CSR loads JavaScript first and renders in the browser; SSR renders HTML on the server per request; SSG pre-renders HTML at build time.
options.explanation: CSR delays first render but enables rich interactivity; SSR improves SEO and first load but adds server cost; SSG is best for static content with CDN delivery.

options.text: CSR is faster than SSR in all cases.
SSG cannot be cached on CDN.

title: This is incorrect. Please refer to system design best practices.
content: Describe how virtual DOM improves rendering performance in frontend frameworks.
explanation: The virtual DOM is an in-memory representation of the UI. Instead of updating the real DOM directly, frameworks update the virtual DOM and compute the minimal changes, which are then applied to the real DOM.

title: Randomized pagination
content: Compare offset-based pagination, cursor-based pagination, and infinite scrolling. Which approach is better for large datasets?
explanation: Offset pagination is simple but slow at scale. Cursor pagination is efficient and consistent. Infinite scroll provides seamless UX but is harder for bookmarking and SEO.

options.text: Offset-based pagination
Cursor-based pagination
Infinite scrolling
Randomized pagination

title: This is incorrect. Please refer to system design best practices.
content: Describe what critical CSS is and how to implement it.
explanation: Critical CSS means extracting the styles needed for above-the-fold content and inlining them in the HTML. This reduces render-blocking requests and improves time-to-first-paint.

title: CSR is always better than SSR
content: Explain the differences between Server-Side Rendering (SSR), Client-Side Rendering (CSR), and Static Site Generation (SSG).
explanation: SSR improves SEO and first load but increases server cost. CSR shifts load to client but may hurt SEO. SSG is fast but static.

options.text: SSR improves SEO but requires servers to render each request
CSR improves interactivity but may delay first paint
SSG pre-renders content, making it very fast for static pages
CSR is always better than SSR
